newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Nigeria's Abacha promises fuel to paralysed Lagos.
newsitem.headline: Nigeria's Abacha promises fuel to paralysed Lagos.

text.p: Nigeria's military strongman General Sani Abacha has ordered petrol to be sent to the commercial capital Lagos, paralysed by fuel scarcity, his close aide said on Tuesday.

Speaking on national television the military governor of Lagos State, Colonel Mohammed Marwa, said Abacha had given the order for the immediate supply of petrol to Lagos and for importation of fuel to avoid long-term shortages.
"In a matter of days things are going to improve," Marwa said. He did not say where the petrol would be found to send to Lagos, with most of the country now suffering shortages.
For over two weeks the hub of Nigerian business has suffered an intensifying fuel shortage which in recent days has spread across the country, including the government capital Abuja.
The bitter irony of fuel shortages in Africa's biggest oil producer has not been lost on a local press which has dubbed it a "national shame".
The state-run Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC) has not given any definite explanation for the shortages, but NNPC officials privately say corruption is partly to blame.
"The ultimate solution is to deregulate the petroleum industry. If that is done the refineries will run profitably and there will be no fuel shortage," said one NNPC official.

Long queues have become a common feature at any pump station dispensing fuel, while a black market is booming with people paying as much 4,000 naira ($47) for a 50-litre (10 gallon) can of petrol, more than seven times the normal price.
Nigeria, a major player in the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC), produces roughly two million barrels a day (bpd) of crude oil.
Of this, 250,000 bpd is allocated to four refineries with a combined capacity to process 445,000 bpd of crude, but they are currently operating well below that.
